title: AB 2362
content: The State of California enacts the following. The State of California enacts Section 4777 of the Civil Code, requiring written notification to owners and tenants in common interest developments before pesticide application, similar to existing law for dwellings. Section 4777 of the Civil Code defines terms related to pesticide application in common interest developments, including definitions for "adjacent separate interest," "authorized agent," "broadcast application," "electronic delivery," "licensed pest control operator," "pest," and "pesticide." (7) “Pesticide” is any substance used to control pests. Associations must provide written notice before applying pesticides without a licensed operator, including information on pests, pesticide brand, and state law requirements. CAUTION – Pesticides are toxic chemicals. Proper use conditions must be followed for unlicensed pesticide use. Contact a healthcare provider if experiencing symptoms after pesticide exposure. For more information, contact the County Health Department or Department of Pesticide Regulation. The association must provide notice of pesticide application, including date, time, and frequency, to owners and tenants 48 hours in advance. For common areas, notice must be posted or provided individually to adjacent owners and tenants. If the pest poses an immediate threat to health and safety, the association must post written notice within one hour after pesticide application. Notice to tenants can be provided through mail, personal delivery, or electronic delivery. Owners or tenants can agree in writing to immediate pesticide application upon receipt of notification. Prior to notification, the association can orally agree to immediate pesticide application if requested by the owner or tenant. Prior to receiving written notification, the association or authorized agent can orally agree to immediate pesticide application if requested by the owner or tenant. A written notice must be left at the separate interest before pesticide application. If other owners or tenants need to be notified, they should receive the notice promptly after the oral agreement is made. A written notice must be attached to the board meeting minutes after pesticide application.
